messageBody:
Pico Geyer wrote:

> For example how do you test a:
> 1) Method that only modifies private fields and has no corresponding
> getter method to see if the field is now at the correct value

If there is no directly-visible effect of a method, then you must either:

(1) Use an indirectly visible effect to see whether the method did its
job. (Ex: change on disk, in a database, e-mail sent)

(2) Create a directly-visible effect "just for testing".

Some people are nervous about option #2, but I'm not. Testing is
important enough. If you're concerned about hiding these extra methods
from client, then hide them behind an interface.

> 2) Methods that work on network traffic, ex counting all TCP packets
> that I receive. I would need an isolated environment and would need to
> be able to send X amount of packets to my machine.

What are you trying to test?

1. That the TCP/IP library you use works.
2. That you can properly use the TCP/IP library.

There are much different approaches for these two.
